Posts.Title: AC every 2 weeks..? susan13 Keryl

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 11:55PM susan13 wrote: Karen, About the hair.  It started to come out some today which is 14 days since my first treatment. My scalp hurts when I touch it, which I hear is a sign that it's going to happen.  I went to a wig salon to pick out a wig even before my first treatment and I highly recommend that.  You need to be prepared on this one.  My husband is going to buzz my hair in the next 2 days, and come Monday morning I will be showing off my new hair do at work.  If you are not a wig person you can get some cute hats and scarfs, they really do have many nice things out there these days.  I opted for a nice wig that was very close to my original hair style and color, as I work in a large coporate office and am in the open all the time, and I would feel more comfortable with a wig on. Sue
Posts.Title: AC every 2 weeks..? susan13 Keryl

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 11:50PM susan13 wrote: Hi Karen, and thanks everyone! The 2nd dose of AC knocked me out a litlte more then the first one, was just way more tired after I got home which at noon yesterday and now I'm wide awake at 2:30 in the morning... thank you steroids! Karen, I was so nervous about starting the treatments, and I got a little nervous again yesterday morning. It's such unknown territory, we don't know what is going to happen or how it will make us feel...I can tell you that so far for me it is not that bad!  I take off the day of treatment and the day after, which is a Thursday and a Friday, relax on the weekend, try to do a little here and there, but nothing to overdo it.  Then I'm good for work on Monday.  After my 1st treatment I was actually able to put in full 8 hour days until my 2nd treatment.  Drinking tons and tons of water is a must.  You can get dehydrated very quickly, keep drinking alot every day.  I have had absolutely no nausea or vomiting, so far, knock on wood!  I am taking Emend and Zofran for that and it seems to be working like a charm.  My biggest problem honestly so far is being kept awake from the steroids.  I dont know if everyone gets the steroids.  If you do you can ask for a light sleeping pill and it will help out.  Also the week after treatment you do get constipated pretty bad, so take a stool soffner every night! Best of luck to you and keep strong, as everyone else will say, and has said to me, it is "doable".  You will have days where you feel like u can run a marathon, and days that you just can't stay awake. Take the good days to their advantage!! Good luck and let us know how you make out! Sue
Posts.Title: AC every 2 weeks..? susan13 Keryl

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2010 12:21PM susan13 wrote: Jenn, I also get 190mg, I am on the every 3 week schedule also. My biggest thing so far, and I've only had 2 treatments, is a horrible sinus headache on day 3 and 4, and NOTHING helps...except by day 5 it's gone. Sue
Posts.Title: abraxane and amount of dosage jleigh anniebford

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 12:06PM susan13 wrote: Linda, I had DCIS, twice, each breast took a turn.  If I would have know back then... first dx 1995, then 2003.  I had neither radiation nor chemo, just lumpectomy's at both times.  Last year I was dx'd with an invasive cancer, in both breasts.  I just completed 8 rounds of chemo, had a bilat. mast., and am almost done with 25 radiation treatments.  I guess what I am trying to say is to treat it aggressively NOW so that it doesn't come back and grow into an invasive cancer. Cause this journey is not a fun one.  I'm sure everyone has their own opinion on DCIS, but just wanted to share with you my experience with it. Best to you, Sue

Posts.Title: Dx'd 9/3 and I am already seeing changes susan13 susan13

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 01:13PM susan13 wrote: Just as I was starting to feel ready for this Friday... we went for a 2nd opinion today.  The oncologist looked at my breast and mentioned inflammatory breast cancer.  That was the last that my brain was able to take in. Threw me for a loop.  It's not red or really swollen, but the skin in the underneath part of the breast is dimpling like the skin of an orange but the color is normal.  From what I understand inflammatory bc is a clinical diagnosis... by sight... so I am going to mention this to my doctor tomorrow when I have my appointment with him to go over Friday's first treatment. On top of that, I had to go back to the hospital this morning to have my port taken out and repositioned.. I was having irregular heart beats last nite and this morning so I rushed over there! Talk about something u do not need !
Posts.Title: Dx'd 9/3 and I am already seeing changes susan13 susan13

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 01:29PM susan13 wrote: Hi Diane, I had dose dense AC also (then dd Taxotere).  It is supposed to be more aggressive, but that would just be some onc.'s. opinions, as they all seem to be different.  I did the neulasta shot after each chemo also, and I took tylenol for 3 days after, and I had no problem with the aches and pains that Neulasta can cause.  Just look on the bright side, if you can... the dose dense treatments will be over with quicker! Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 01:03PM susan13 wrote: Simone, Chemo is usually always given these days for an invasive breast cancer unless it's very small. Depends on the pathology. I assume all you've had done so far is a biopsy? What did the results of that say? My decision on the implants was a no brainer for me.  I wanted to see myself as close to how I was before this cancer came along and invaded my life.  And I have to tell you I really feel great!  If you do decide on immediate reconstruction you need to find a plastic surgeon.  It took a full 7 days for my breast surgeon and plastic surgeon to coordinate their schedules so they can be in the surgery room at the same time/day.  Maybe you should go for a consult and talk to a plastic surgeon so that you can understand the process a little more, it sure won't hurt. Sue
Posts.Title: I am so confused as to which route to take jancie Beesie

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 11:27AM susan13 wrote: Simonejones, Yes I had 4 underarm nodes removed and they all had cancer.  My plan is to do 4 additional chemo treatments, then about 4 weeks later have my exchange surgery.  Then 4 weeks after that radiation to my breast area, underarm and node area under the collarbone. I got a small fill in my expanders during the intial surgery and I have been going for fills every week.  I'll start to have larger fills so that I can get to my desired size by the end of my chemo treatments. Sue

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 10:38AM susan13 wrote: Ruth, Sorry you are here.  I agree that whatever surgical choice, it is a personal decision.  I also had both DCIS and invasive disease, altho at the time of my mastectomy, and after 4 rounds of chemo, the DCIS turned into an invasive tumor.  So I am glad I decided on a bilat mast.  I also had immediate reconstruction, which I am also glad I decided to do.  I am 43 with a 2 year old baby girl, and I know that we both will see our daughters grow up!  Treatment today is alot better then it was 20 years ago, you can have faith in that. Good luck in your decision. Sue

I think I'll try in about a month and get some funky highlights and give it some flare! Isn't it funny how after everything else we have gone thru... chemo, surgery! radiation... our hair is for some reason the one thing that seems to be the most sensitive to deal with!?!?  I have no problem waltzing around with my temporary fake boobies (aka tissue expanders), but when it came to taking my wig off in public I was a basket case!   Go figure........

Yesterday I had a bit of an anxiety attack during the plethera of ct scans and I thought I was having a heart attack, the tech had to stop and come out and make sure I was ok, waited for me to calm down to resume the rest of the scans. Did you work thru your treatments?  Sue

Posts.Title: How long for skin to heal? Linda37 susan13

Posts.Content: susan13 wrote: Ok so it wasn't THAT bad. Thank goodness for the Ativan they pumped into me prior to starting the ACF cause after that I didn't really care what was going on.  Hubby was a diferent story. Had a horrible nights sleep... actually a entire lack of sleep.  They told me the Decadron would "disrupt" my sleep... eliminate it was more like it! Took Emend and Zofran and so far so good.  Getting the metallic taste in my mought and appetite is starting to go bye bye.  I really need to chug water constantly! Got the shot of Neulasta this morning and I'll see where that takes me. Other than that... so far so good. Oh one thing I would love to share with everyone... yesterday morning about 2 hours before I was leaving for treatment I get the most sincerest precious picture on my cell phone... my wonderful 11 year old niece Brianna cut off her long beautiful hair to donate in my honor.  Then her 9 year old sister did the samet thing that afternoon.  Kids just know the right thing to make you smile don't they!? Sue You can't change the past but you can ruin the present by worrying over the future. suesbadboobs.blogspot.com dd CAF bilat mast. w/recon. dd Txo. 25 rads. Tamoxifen. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Day 1 and 2 susan13 susan13

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 09:38AM susan13 wrote: Genia, How are you feeling today?  It's no picnic but every day you will feel better!  I feel so good today, I feel like I can go walk for a few miles! Aggie... Last nite I finally slept for 4 1/2 hours straight! wohooo!  That is good for me considering the last 5 nites.  I will talk to my onc. tomorrow about it.  Wasn't restless, had no nausea or pain, my heart rate was up a bit and has been since tx day 1, but this morning it was finally normal!  The decadron was given to me via IV just before they started the chemo, maybe it took a little while to get out of my system.  Hey a glass of wine though does sound good! It's been a while! Good wishes and happy thoughts to everyone! Sue
Posts.Title: Day 1 and 2 susan13 susan13

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2009 03:52AM susan13 wrote: I am so sorry for your sister's dx.  But she is very lucky to have you.  It's a long road and not an easy one, but she will get thru it, just like the rest of us.  She'll need help with her children during treatment, and I think that will be most important to her.  I have a 2 year old and that really is the hardest part of this whole thing.  Seems as though her doctors are being very aggressive and moving along quickly which is good.  Good luck to your sister! Sue
Posts.Title: How do I help my sister??? wanting_to_help wanting_to_help

Posts.Content: susan13 wrote:  Ok 2 treatments in on CAF to shrink what was first measured as a 10cm x 11cm tumor... yeah a real big one!  This morning my onc. measured it at 8cm x 8cm... so hey that's something right?!? He also said because I have this fibrocystic disease on top of it (3 fibroids and 1 cyst), it's kinda hard to actually "feel" where the actual tumor really is, and the Pet scan had fuzzy margins so that didn't give us an accurate measurement either.  So I'm wondering if it's possible that this tumor really isn't as big as it's being clinically measured?! Well I feel a little better now knowing that this poison going into my body every 2 weeks is indeed doing some good!! Sue You can't change the past but you can ruin the present by worrying over the future. suesbadboobs.blogspot.com dd CAF bilat mast. w/recon. dd Txo. 25 rads. Tamoxifen. Log in to post a reply

But when I started eatting I felt much better.  Even got out to the park with my daughter this afternoon.  Naps seems to be the key, even if I just sit still for 30 minutes. Aggie, I picked out a wig and will be going back to the salon when my hair starts to thin and fall out and the hairdresser/owner of the salon will give my head a buzz and she'll fit the wig on and style it the way I want... Posts.Title: What's your wierdest side effect ann-idiot ann-idiot

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 07:29AM susan13 wrote: Hi Ladies, Kelty and those others just dx'd with little ones... I was dx'd when my baby girl was 18 months old. It's definitely a roller coaster ride going thru this as it is but with an infant/toddler it's even more so.  I had 4 chemo treatments then a bilaterial mastectomy and now I am getting ready to have more chemo treatments. After that I'll have my exchange surgery then radiation treatments.  My biggest fear was how I was going to take care of her while going thru all of this, especially the surgery, but it really does all work out.  Take it day by day and have fun with your babies cause they really are the bright light in all of this for you.  Don't let this get you down as tough as it may be. Try to go about your normal every day routine cause that really does help! Sue
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 04:16PM susan13 wrote: This had and still has me confused too. I was told by an oncologist that the statistical survival rates published are for diagnosis alone, and does not include a treatment plan whether it's chemo or radiation.  Chemo, I was told, increases the survival rate by 33%.  So say a Stage 3 has a 54% of 5 year survival, then add chemo to that your rate goes up to 87%.... does this sound right? ... anyone else been told this?

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 03:06PM susan13 wrote: I had a tumor in each breast.  It doesn't change the staging or seriousness of it.  If it's there in one breast long enough I think the odds of it going to the other is common. Best luck to your mom!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 03:49PM susan13 wrote: I just started taking COQ10 again, 100mg. Used to take it many many years ago when I developed a bad valve in my heart.  I noticed when I took it regularly I did not get palpitations anymore.  I think it's a pretty good supplement to take.  So sorry about your CHF. Darn chemo! Hope you can get better and feel stronger. Purchasing it online is much cheaper then at a store. I get mine from either Vitacost.com, or Puritan's Pride.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 03:01PM susan13 wrote: Hi Ladies, Joining the January group. I start Taxol Jan. 22nd, will try to get thru 4 treatments.  Already had 4 AC's prior to bilat. mast. with tissue expanders.  I'm 5 weeks post opt. tomorrow and feeling pretty good.  Unfortunately I had 4 pos. nodes so hence the Taxol.  My Onc. says it'll be "easier" then AC and I guess I'll find out soon enough.. After treatments are done I have my exchange surgery then onto rads. I think by the time I'll be all done it'll be the end of summer which will be one year since dx. Sure is a long road isn't it?!? Sue
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 07:02AM susan13 wrote: I'd get it checked out anyway.  I had a biopsy on calcifications that came up first as DCIS, also known as pre-invasive or non-cancerous or stage 0. This was from a stereotactic biopsy, but then during mastectomy turned out to be a tiny invasive lobular cancer.
Posts.Title: Are microcalcifications pre cancerous? naturegirl2 flowingspirit

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 11:57AM susan13 wrote: Hello Ladies, I'm joining the January chemo group.  Had bilat. mast. with tissue expanders on Dec. 9th.  Onc. will let me know my exact treatment plan this Friday.  I know it'll be Taxol/Taxotere and possibly carblotin(sp?). Just not sure how many tx's or how far apart.  After chemo I'll need to do rads.  One of my margins was a bit close at .1cm, and I had 4 positive nodes.  I already did chemo, 4 tx's of AC from September to October.  Originally they thought my tmor was 8-10cm, but when taken out it was just 1.8cm.  Big difference. I had alot of abnormal things going on in the boob that made it swell up and get hard. So they thought it was all tumor.  I'm sure the AC kicked it down a bit too.  My hair started to grow back, but it'll fall out again of course. BUMMER.  I worked thru my AC treatments, except for the day of and after tx.  But, not sure how I will be for TC. Anyone work thru TC?? I hope I can cause it does help me emotionally to go about my daily routine thru this entire thing. Thanks for listening!  Good luck to everyone starting this month. Sue
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 02:13PM susan13 wrote: My PS says it's ok to do it either way, but I have opted to have the rads first,then wait about 6 months for exchange.  PS says that way if something happens to the expander he can at least fix it during exchange.  If you have exchange first and something goes wrong with expander due to rads then u r looking at another surgery.  At least that's the way it was put to me.
Posts.Title: Exchange before Radiation? Scrappygrl nurlaw

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 10:06AM susan13 wrote: Thanks Ladies, We are trying and practicing getting her used to things now, like going down the stairs on her heiny, and I'll work on the car seat thing this weekend. Also having her sit on my lap when reading books and watching tv.  She's starting to be in that independent stage now where she finds a need to do everything herself, like a big girl, so maybe that will work on our favor! Sue MB p.s.  having immed. recon with tissue expanders

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 09:53AM susan13 wrote: Wow everyminute just 6 months out???!!!!!!!! You are looking amazing!   My hair is coming in nicely and it's starting to turn thick, BUT the top is wavy and the back is straight... hmmmmmm not sure how that will all turn out. Maybe the wavy's will turn straight cause there is still some fuzzies in there....
Posts.Title: status report and hair pic everyminute KerryMac

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 02:49PM susan13 wrote: Are you eligible for FMLA (Family Medical Leave Act)?  If you are I heard that you can use that for days that are needed to take off for your cancer treatments.  I am lucky, my employer of 19 years is working with me and giving me the 2 days needed to take off of treatment twice per month.  I do however check my company email from home, and if there's anything I can do workwise from home, if I am up to it, I do it. Your job is safe... they cannot fire you, so do not worry about that.  They also cannot force you to take disability.  Try contacting your local government on labor laws in your state. Good luck! Sue
Posts.Title: Employees and Employers Jlaw4545 NancyD

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 07:21PM - edited Feb 27, 2009 07:25PM by susan13 Hunger for me too.  Also no sleep for the first week but maybe a couple/few hours a night.  I start taking the Dex the night before my treatment, 8 mgs, then in the morning another 8 mgs, then during treatment 15mgs in my IV. Then the following 3 days I take 4 mgs twice a day.  But my last treatment my Onc. told me to cut the dosage in half, and it's working that way for me too.  BUT the withdrawal from it like Kerry said is horrible!   I don't know why we have to be so dosed up with the stuff. I hear some women don't even take the dex at all, except in the IV. Oh... I'm on Taxotere by the way, different side effects then other chemo's, I didn't do the Dex on AC.
Posts.Title: Dexamethasone Husband11 Vavoom10

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 02:03PM susan13 wrote: My advise, and it is from personal experience, is to NOT mess around with DCIS.  I had DCIS twice without radiation.  Now I have a bilaterial cancer.  Had DCIS 4 years ago with just a lumpectomy no rads, and now it is back in the same exact spot.  Also had it in the other breast 12 years ago, now in that breast I have an invasaive lobular carcinoma. Please take it as seriuosly as you would an invasive disease! Sue
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed DCIS & Need Members Advice G696 susan13

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2008 08:48AM susan13 wrote: Thanks! Did your onc. give you coumadin for this?  Mine gave me 1mg to start taking the day after I have the port inserted. I'm assuming it's for clotting issues.?
Posts.Title: Port? susan13 Coltsneck

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 11:54AM - edited Jul 8, 2009 11:57AM by susan13 Hi Carole, Sorry you are here!! I too had very long thick hair but I found a wig that really did match quit well and no one could tell it was even a wig!  It was a Louis Ferre "Jennifer".  I bought it at a local salon, but afterwards found out that I could have saved about $200 if I bought it online. But of course it's tough the first time buying a wig online when you can't try it on, and you can't return them either.  You can look on my blog as I have pictures there (of all my wigs, but the long one was my first.)  Here is a good online source for wigs, I have bought a couple from. This is the one I mentioned http://www.wigsalon.com/wigx.htm?wig=534.  I recommend a wig with a "monofiliament cap" definitely. It gives the appearance of a real part, and they are just made better.  After a while I started having fun with having to wear wigs and started to go shorter and shorter.  I lost my hair twice, cause I had to do chemo twice, so my wig wearing days lasted 10 months. Good luck with the chemo. It's not an easy road, but it's the road you need to travel to get all that cancer out of your body!!!  Keep hydrated and rest alot. Sue
Posts.Title: scared, start chemo 7/20 Carole01 marlenet

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 10:23AM susan13 wrote: Depends, what is your actual diagnosis (type, stage, grade, node involvement, etc.) ? I am doing chemo prior to surgery and I started 2 weeks after diagnosis.  So I'm in a different boat then you, but I am sure others will give you some insight on what their plan was.  But look at it this way, at least the cancer was cut out of you.  Assuming when you say "treatment" , you will be having chemo or rads now? Good luck to you! Sue

Posts.Title: Port? susan13 Coltsneck

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 03:42PM - edited Oct 10, 2008 03:56PM by susan13 I can't figure out how to send a pic with a private message, so I just changed my picture on my profile.  If you want send me your email address and I will be more than glad to send you some more clear pictures.  Here's something to make you laugh... I started wearing my wig for the first time this Monday morning... I work in a large corporate office for an executive... so I was kinda insecure about coming in the first day with my wig... so I was taking pictures of me on the way in in my car with my cell phone... just to see how I looked!  Today I didn't have to do it! Also look for a salon specifically that does wigs for cancer patients.  That's what I did, I didn't even have to pick the wig out. The salon owner sat me in a chair, told me she'd be right back , and when she came back she put this wig on my head and I can't tell you how big the smile was on my face! The service from these shops are more personalized and they really do know what we are going thru.  If you go to a normal wig shop you might not get that kind of service. Sue
Posts.Title: Hair System???? Mocity abbadoodles

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 02:36PM susan13 wrote: CristlC, I almost went for one of these hair systems myself. The cost was about $1500-$2000. I went so far to make an appointment at a salon in New York City who did this, and clients were some celebrities.  But then I decided against it, and I am so gald I did.  I am comfortable with my regular run of the mill synthetic wig (if you want to see a picture of me wearing it let me know and I'll send you a private message).  The scalp issue is true, I am seeing some drys spots especially along my hair line above my forehead so you might want to think about that also. Another thing is that how long do you think you'll need a "temporary" hair piece?  That was kind of my decision maker.  Usually all of us are looking at maybe a year or so.  Also I wear scarfs and hats at home on the weekends, and the minute I get home after work I tear my wig off and it feels great! I'm not ashamed of having no hair, my husband doesn't mind, and my daughter thinks it's funny! And I get so many compliments from my co-workers on my wig... many of them don't even know it's a wig! Good luck to you! Sue
Posts.Title: Hair System???? Mocity abbadoodles
